newsitem.title: GERMANY: German call money slips to 2.98/3.03 percent.
newsitem.headline: German call money slips to 2.98/3.03 percent.

text.p: German call money rates were slightly lower in dealings on Friday, slipping to 2.98/3.03 percent from around 3.05 percent on Thursday amid signs of adequate market liquidity, traders said.

Call money rates slipped slightly below the Bundesbank's fixed repo rate at 3.00 percent as commercial bank reserves at the Bundesbank were nearing minimum levels and banks dumped excess funds ahead of the weekend, traders said.
"The reserve level for May is adequate but that does not mean we necessarily have excess liquidity," one Frankfurt money market trader said.
The Bundesbank said on Friday that banks held 41.1 billion marks in reserves as of Thursday, while the monthly average rose to 40.6 billion marks. Lombard borrowings were negligible.
Traders expected rates to remain slightly under pressure early next week amid market predictions for few troubles in banks meeting month-end reserve requirements.
"A few traders are consciously short going into the month's end because of expectations for lower rates," a trader said.
The Frankfurt Interbank Overnight Average on Friday was at 3.04333 percent compared with 3.06933 percent on Thursday.
